meanings.def: the total amount of crops, profits, etc. that are produced
examples: a high crop yield
a reduction in milk yield
This will give a yield of 10% on your investment.
This method of cultivation produces higher yield.
Yields are quite poor this year.
savings products which offer high yields

meanings.def: to produce or provide something, for example a profit, result or crop
examples: Higher-rate deposit accounts yield good returns.
The research has yielded useful information.
These trees no longer yield fruit.
The project is expected to yield good returns in future.

meanings.def: to stop resisting something/somebody; to agree to do something that you do not want to do
examples: After a long siege, the town was forced to yield.
yield to something/somebody He reluctantly yielded to their demands.
I yielded to temptation and had a chocolate bar.
He finally yielded to her demands.
They refused to yield to public pressure.

meanings.def: to allow somebody to win, have or take control of something that has been yours until now
examples: He refused to yield up his gun.
(figurative) The universe is slowly yielding up its secrets.
archaeological remains which are yielding up secrets from long ago

meanings.def: to move, bend or break because of pressure
examples: Despite our attempts to break it, the lock would not yield.

meanings.def: to allow vehicles on a bigger road to go first
examples: Yield to oncoming traffic.
a yield sign
